SENT.plain: The autonomic nervous system, in particular vagal function, plays an important role in a wide range of somatic and mental disorders

Cardiac vagal function can be indexed by the respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA) - oscillations in heart rate linked to respiration mediated predominantly by fluctuations of vagus nerve efferent traffic originating in the nucleus ambiguus
Moreover, the neurocardiac vagal modulation has been shown to be related to physiological adaptability/flexibity and emotional regulation
Thus, greater vagal withdrawal during stressors and subsequent recovery should be indicative of a more flexible physiological response system
Importantly, the vagal inhibitory function plays a key role in the regulation of allostatic processes including the immune response (cholinergic anti-inflammatory pathway)
Decreased cardiovagal function (lower RSA) was shown to be associated with increased proinflammatory markers and acute-phase proteins indicating increased allostatic load and poor health
Thus, the study of the vagal-immune interactions could help illuminate the pathway via which psychosocial factors may influence health and disease
